title: 114_hr2532
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2016" and includes cost savings enhancements. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2016" includes definitions related to surplus salaries and expenses funds in agencies. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2016" allows for the identification and rescission of unnecessary funds in agencies, as determined by various agency officials. The act also amends Section 4512 of title 5, United States Code, to grant authority for these actions. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2016" amends Section 4512 of title 5, United States Code to allow for the identification and rescission of surplus salaries and expenses funds in agencies. The Inspector General or designated agency employee must refer any potential surplus funds to the Chief Financial Officer of the agency. The Chief Financial Officer of the agency transfers surplus funds to the Treasury for deficit reduction or debt reduction as per Section 4511(a)(2). The agency's Chief Financial Officer transfers surplus funds to the Treasury for deficit reduction. The agency head can retain up to 10% of these funds, which can be used for cash awards to employees who identified the surplus funds. Any remaining amounts can be transferred or reprogrammed for agency use. The agency's Chief Financial Officer transfers surplus funds to the Treasury for deficit reduction, with the agency head retaining up to 10% for cash awards to employees who identified the surplus funds. Any remaining amounts can be transferred or reprogrammed for agency use. Each agency must submit reports to the Secretary of the Treasury on savings achieved through disclosures of fraud, waste, or mismanagement, and identification of surplus funds by employees. The agency must report cash awards and savings achieved through employee disclosures to the Treasury. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management ensures agency compliance with cash award programs. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2016 requires agencies to comply with cash award programs and submit annual certifications to Congress. The Comptroller General must report on the program's operation every 3 years, with potential legislative recommendations. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2016 mandates agencies to adhere to cash award programs and provide yearly certifications to Congress. The act prohibits cash awards for certain officers, including those at level I of the Executive Schedule, agency heads, and members of independent establishments. The table of sections for chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by removing section 4509 and inserting a new item. Prohibition of cash award to certain officers.
